content.description:
This problem climbs using some big slaps up an arete and some crimps. 

  Start using either of two left hand crimps, one is bigger but further away, and a right hand as low as you can (or want to) on the right arete. Bump up to a really good hold on the arete, then make a big slap up the arete the an awesome hold that has a perfect little divot-oval cut out that fits 4 fingers. From here figure out how to get a slopey jug up high and work up and left and top at as for Lichen It.  

  This climb is kinda morpho, as Brad couldn't span where I started, so people with shorter spans might have to just start matched on the arete, or higher up on the arete. I think the best option would be to climb it as a jump start, left on the crimp then jump up and catch right on the arete up high.
content.protection: Two pads at least, a spotter is nice too.
content.location: On the same boulder as Lichen It, a couples minutes left into the woods from the gazebo.

content.description:
This is a cool climb with a low crux and couple committing moves up high.  

  Start with jug left and low on the arete, and a crimp out right. Pull off the ground with difficulty and make a hard move to bump up the arete. Find your feet and get your right hand to some higher holds, then get your hand in a great, somewhat hidden hold in a crack/seam. Use some trickery to get from there to the arete up and right. From there make one more move to a jug on the lip and top 'er out, you'll be lichen it.
content.protection: The landing is pretty bad but it's easy to make it a workable landing with two pads. A spotter is nice as well to shout words of encouragement for the top.
content.location: This is a couple minutes further down in the south end from the Welcome Boulders, it climbs a nice face that has a very rotten, fallen tree 20' in front of it, and is between a couple of other boulders.

content.description: Sit start in the center of the boulder with a hidden left hand undercling and a right hand slopey crystal crimp. Find a way to put weight on your left foot and make a couple hard left hand moves to gain a good sidepull flake. Move right hand up to another sidepull flake then make a big move up lefty onto the slab to a crystal nub and top her out.
content.location: This problem is located on the south side of the gazebo a few boulders behind the elemental boulder. It’s about a 15 foot wide and 12 foot tall boulder with a straight face that turns into slab around 7 feet up.

content.description: Sit start under the roof with a small crimp flake for the left and the arete for the right. Pull on and move the left hand out the arete. Throw up a heel hook and cross to an awesome pinch on the arete. Mantel over and grab a few holds. Don't dab and watch out for the rock to the left. Low and short on a unique rock and a nice arete.
content.location: This lowball roof is located uphill from Lone Wolf about 15 yards and hard to miss.

content.description:
This is an okay little climb. With some more cleaning it will be better.  

  Start on a little sloper dish thing, then find some feet, get to the left arete and finish up on the left face.
content.protection: 1 or 2 pads and maybe a spotter
content.location: On the little boulder to the left of Coyotes.

content.description: A sub-area for the smaller boulders or one move wonders.
